thread.title_full: Qld man in court over boy s Xmas death - Yahoo7

author: Melissa Grant
title: Qld man in court over boy s Xmas death - Yahoo7
text:
Man accused of running over boy on Christmas Day while three-times legal limit Melissa Grant - AAP on February 14, 2017, 11:38 am Qld man in court over boy's Xmas death (clone 1487043558) Share Qld man in court over boy s Xmas death - Yahoo7 A Queensland man charged over an alleged drink-driving incident that claimed the life of a nine-year-old boy on Christmas night is doing it pretty tough, his lawyer says. 
Adrian Murray, 24, is accused of being more than three times over the legal alcohol limit when he ran over Josiah Sisson as the boy looked at Christmas lights with his family in Springwood, south of Brisbane. 
Murray, who is on bail, briefly faced court for the first time on Tuesday. Adrian Murray briefly faced court for the first time on Tuesday. Source: 7News 
Outside, defence lawyer Andrew Moloney said his client was doing as well as could be expected in the circumstances. 
"(He is) doing it pretty tough as is everyone involved in this I think - it's terrible," he said. 
It's alleged Murray had a blood-alcohol concentration of 0.162 when his car struck Josiah on Christmas night. 
The schoolboy died in hospital two days later after his family chose to take him off life support. 
His father Karl Sisson, a pastor, astonished many when he met with Murray and forgave him for causing his son's death. It's alleged Murray had a blood-alcohol concentration of 0.162 when his car struck Josiah. Source: 7News 
Murray is facing charges of dangerous operation of a vehicle causing death while adversely affected by an intoxicating substance and driving a motor vehicle while under the influence. 
His case was adjourned on Tuesday to allow police to prepare a brief of evidence. 
Mr Moloney told reporters he would wait for the brief before deciding how to proceed with the case. 
He didn't indicate whether Murray has had any recent contact with Josiah's family, saying that was private. 
The case is due to return to the Beenleigh Magistrates Court on April 18.
